research_question: How do changes in credit market conditions (e.g., credit availability, interest rates, loan defaults) affect individuals' mental health outcomes?
data: Micro-level data linking individuals' credit histories and financial behaviors with their mental health status, potentially using survey data or administrative records.
methods: Econometric analysis to establish a causal relationship between credit market conditions and mental health indicators, controlling for confounding factors.
main_results: Tighter credit market conditions and increased financial distress are associated with a higher prevalence of mental health issues, such as depression and anxiety. This effect is particularly pronounced for individuals with high levels of debt or limited access to credit.
implications: Financial policies and credit market regulations can have indirect but significant impacts on public health. Interventions aimed at improving financial literacy and access to affordable credit may also have positive mental health benefits.

title: Prediction-Driven Surge Planning with Applications to Emergency Departments
background: Emergency departments (EDs) often face unpredictable surges in patient volume, leading to operational challenges, long wait times, and reduced quality of care. Proactive planning based on accurate predictions is crucial.
research_question: How can predictive models be used to anticipate patient surges in emergency departments and inform proactive resource allocation and surge planning?
data: Historical patient arrival data, admission data, and resource utilization data from emergency departments.
methods: Development and application of machine learning and statistical forecasting models to predict patient volume and acuity. Simulation and optimization techniques to evaluate the effectiveness of different surge planning strategies based on these predictions.
main_results: Predictive models can accurately forecast short-term patient surges in EDs, allowing for more effective proactive resource management. Surge planning strategies informed by these predictions can reduce wait times, improve patient flow, and optimize staff allocation.
implications: Hospitals and healthcare systems can improve ED operational efficiency and patient care by implementing prediction-driven surge planning. This approach can lead to better preparedness for unexpected demand and more resilient healthcare delivery.

title: Managerial Overextrapolation: Who and When
background: Corporate managers sometimes overextrapolate past earnings trends when making future projections, leading to suboptimal decisions. Understanding when and why this occurs is important for corporate governance and financial analysis.
research_question: Under what conditions do managers tend to overextrapolate past earnings, and which types of managers are more prone to this bias?
data: Financial statement data, managerial characteristics (e.g., tenure, compensation structure), and firm-specific information.
methods: Econometric analysis of a large sample of firms to identify the determinants of managerial overextrapolation, using proxies for past earnings trends and future expectations.
main_results: Managerial overextrapolation is more likely to occur during periods of high earnings volatility and when managers have shorter tenures or incentives tied to short-term performance. Managers with less experience or those operating in less transparent environments are also more susceptible.
implications: Investors and boards of directors should be aware of the potential for managerial overextrapolation, especially in certain market conditions or with specific types of managers. This awareness can help in evaluating forecasts and making more robust strategic decisions.

title: Taylor Approximation of Inventory Policies for Distribution Systems
background: Optimizing inventory policies in complex distribution systems is crucial for managing costs and ensuring product availability. Traditional methods can be computationally intensive or rely on simplifying assumptions.
research_question: Can Taylor approximations be effectively used to develop efficient and accurate inventory policies for multi-echelon distribution systems?
data: Data from a simulated distribution system with various demand patterns and lead times.
methods: Development of inventory control models using Taylor series expansions to approximate complex functions, and comparison of the performance of these approximate policies with existing optimal or heuristic policies.
main_results: Taylor approximations can provide good approximations of optimal inventory policies in certain distribution system settings, offering a computationally efficient alternative to more complex optimization methods. The accuracy of the approximation depends on the system's characteristics and the order of the Taylor expansion.
implications: This research offers a practical approach for optimizing inventory management in complex supply chains, potentially leading to cost savings and improved service levels.

title: The Financial Consequences of Online Review Aggregation
background: Online reviews have become a significant source of information for consumers. Review aggregation platforms synthesize these reviews, potentially influencing consumer choices and firm performance.
research_question: What are the financial consequences for firms when their products or services are featured on online review aggregation platforms?
data: Data on firms' financial performance (e.g., sales, stock prices) and their presence and ratings on major online review aggregation platforms.
methods: Econometric analysis to link the visibility and sentiment of aggregated online reviews to firm-level financial outcomes, using event study methodologies around platform introductions or major changes.
main_results: Positive aggregated reviews and high visibility on aggregation platforms are associated with increased sales and improved stock market performance. Conversely, negative reviews can lead to significant financial losses.
implications: Firms need to actively manage their online reputation and engage with customer feedback, as it has tangible financial implications. Review aggregation platforms play a crucial role in shaping market perceptions and firm value.

title: Platform Financing vs. Trade Credit for Lending Businesses
background: Businesses that extend credit to their customers (lending businesses) face decisions about how to finance their operations. They can rely on platform financing (e.g., from fintech platforms) or traditional trade credit.
research_question: Under what conditions is platform financing more advantageous than trade credit for lending businesses, and vice versa?
data: Data from lending businesses, including their financing choices, operational characteristics, and performance metrics.
methods: A theoretical model comparing the costs and benefits of platform financing and trade credit, followed by empirical analysis to test the model's predictions using real-world data.
main_results: Platform financing offers greater flexibility and potentially lower costs in certain scenarios, especially for rapidly growing businesses or those seeking to diversify funding sources. Trade credit remains competitive for established businesses with stable cash flows and strong supplier relationships.
implications: Lending businesses can make more informed financing decisions by understanding the trade-offs between platform financing and trade credit based on their specific circumstances and market conditions.

title: Securities Markets in Which Some Investors Receive Information About Future Prices
background: Securities markets are often characterized by information asymmetry, where some market participants have superior information compared to others. This study focuses on a specific scenario where some investors receive advance information about future prices.
research_question: How does the presence of informed investors, who receive information about future prices, affect market efficiency, price discovery, and the welfare of different market participants?
data: Theoretical modeling and simulation of securities market dynamics under different information structures.
methods: Development of a dynamic equilibrium model of a securities market with heterogeneous beliefs and informed traders. Analysis of the model's predictions regarding price behavior and trading volume.
main_results: The presence of informed investors can accelerate price discovery and improve market efficiency by incorporating future price information into current prices. However, it can also lead to increased volatility and potential losses for uninformed investors.
implications: Understanding the impact of information asymmetry is crucial for designing fair and efficient securities markets. Regulatory policies may need to consider mechanisms to mitigate the adverse effects on uninformed investors.

title: Asset-Side Bank Runs and Liquidity Rationing: A Theory
background: Bank runs, where depositors withdraw their funds en masse, are a classic financial stability concern. This paper explores a related phenomenon: asset-side bank runs, where the underlying assets of a bank face a run.
research_question: Can a run on a bank's underlying assets lead to liquidity rationing and financial distress, even if depositors do not withdraw their funds?
data: Theoretical modeling of bank behavior and financial markets.
methods: Development of a dynamic model of bank asset markets and liquidity provision. Analysis of equilibrium outcomes under different scenarios of asset market distress.
main_results: A run on a bank's assets, driven by concerns about asset quality or liquidity, can force the bank to sell assets at fire-sale prices, leading to losses and potential insolvency. This can also trigger liquidity rationing, where the bank struggles to obtain necessary funding, even without depositor panic.
implications: This research highlights a less-understood channel through which financial instability can arise, emphasizing the importance of monitoring asset market liquidity and bank asset quality, in addition to depositor behavior.

title: Double Marginalization Because of External Financing
background: Double marginalization occurs when two firms in a supply chain each exert market power, leading to higher prices and lower overall efficiency. This paper examines how external financing can exacerbate this issue.
research_question: How does the availability and cost of external financing influence the extent of double marginalization in a supply chain?
data: Theoretical modeling of supply chain interactions and financing decisions.
methods: A game-theoretic model analyzing the pricing and investment decisions of firms in a supply chain, considering the impact of different financing structures and costs.
main_results: External financing can worsen double marginalization if it allows upstream or downstream firms to increase their market power or invest in capacity that further exploits the supply chain. The cost of financing plays a critical role in determining the magnitude of this effect.
implications: Firms and policymakers should consider the financing structure of supply chain partners when assessing potential inefficiencies. Strategies to mitigate double marginalization may need to account for the role of external capital.

title: Asset Pricing with Costly Short Sales
background: The ability to short sell assets is considered important for price discovery and market efficiency. However, short selling is often costly due to borrowing fees, regulatory constraints, and potential adverse selection.
research_question: How do the costs associated with short selling affect asset prices, volatility, and market efficiency?
data: Theoretical modeling of asset pricing with heterogeneous beliefs and costly short sales.
methods: Development of a dynamic asset pricing model that incorporates the frictions of short selling. Analysis of equilibrium prices, trading behavior, and the implications for market efficiency.
main_results: Costly short sales lead to a divergence between the prices of assets that are easy to short and those that are difficult to short. This can result in mispricing, increased volatility, and reduced market efficiency, as arbitrage opportunities are limited.
implications: Understanding the impact of short-sale constraints is important for asset managers and regulators. Policies aimed at reducing short-selling costs could potentially improve market functioning.

title: Is One Plus One Always Two? Insuring Longevity Risk with Heterogeneous Preferences
background: Longevity risk, the risk of outliving one's financial resources, is a major concern for individuals, especially in retirement. Insurance products exist, but preferences for how this risk is managed can vary significantly.
research_question: How do heterogeneous preferences regarding longevity risk and insurance affect the demand for and design of longevity insurance products?
data: Theoretical modeling of individual decision-making under uncertainty and heterogeneous preferences.
methods: Development of a model that incorporates different attitudes towards risk, time preferences, and beliefs about longevity. Analysis of optimal insurance contracts and individual choices.
main_results: Individuals with different preferences will demand different types and amounts of longevity insurance. Some may prefer simple annuities, while others might seek more complex products that offer flexibility or protection against specific longevity scenarios. The 'one plus one' (i.e., a simple combination of two standard annuities) may not be optimal for everyone.
implications: Insurers can develop more tailored and effective longevity insurance products by understanding the diverse preferences of their customers. Individuals can make better decisions about retirement planning by considering their own unique risk attitudes.

title: Communication Within Firms: Evidence from CEO Communications
background: Effective internal communication is vital for firm performance, but it is often difficult to measure and study. This paper uses CEO communications as a proxy for firm-level communication.
research_question: What is the impact of CEO communication on various aspects of firm performance, such as employee morale, productivity, and stock returns?
data: Firm-level communication data derived from CEO statements, earnings call transcripts, and internal company communications, linked with performance metrics.
methods: Textual analysis of CEO communications to identify sentiment, tone, and key themes. Econometric analysis to link these communication characteristics to firm performance indicators.
main_results: The style and content of CEO communications have a measurable impact on firm outcomes. Positive, transparent, and forward-looking communication is associated with higher employee engagement, better operational performance, and improved stock market valuations.
implications: CEOs and senior management should pay close attention to their communication strategies, as they can significantly influence organizational culture, employee behavior, and ultimately, firm success.

title: Bundling and Line Extensions in Distribution Channels
background: Firms often use bundling (offering multiple products together) and line extensions (introducing new products under an existing brand) as strategies in their distribution channels. The effectiveness of these strategies can depend on various market factors.
research_question: How do bundling and line extensions affect competition, consumer choice, and profitability within distribution channels?
data: Theoretical modeling of firm strategies in distribution channels.
methods: A game-theoretic model analyzing the decisions of manufacturers and retailers regarding product bundling and line extensions, considering consumer preferences and competitive dynamics.
main_results: Bundling can be an effective strategy for firms to differentiate their offerings and increase market share, especially when products are complementary. Line extensions can leverage brand equity but may also lead to cannibalization and increased complexity in the channel.
implications: Firms need to carefully consider the strategic implications of bundling and line extensions, taking into account consumer behavior, competitive responses, and the overall structure of the distribution channel to maximize their benefits.

title: A Better Estimate of Internally Generated Intangibles
background: Internally generated intangible assets (like R&D, brand building) are crucial for firm value but are often not fully captured in traditional accounting statements. This leads to potential underestimation of a firm's true worth.
research_question: How can we develop more accurate methods for estimating the value of internally generated intangible assets?
data: Financial statement data, patent data, R&D expenditure data, and market valuation data for a sample of firms.
methods: Development of new accounting or econometric methods to estimate the value of internally generated intangibles, potentially by linking R&D spending, patenting activity, and market performance.
main_results: Existing methods for valuing internally generated intangibles are often inadequate. The proposed new approach provides a more comprehensive estimate by considering multiple indicators of intangible asset creation and their impact on firm value.
implications: A better understanding and measurement of intangible assets can lead to more accurate financial reporting, better investment decisions, and a more complete picture of firm value.

title: Rise of the Machines: The Impact of Automated Decision-Making on Lending
background: Automated decision-making systems, often powered by AI, are increasingly used in financial services, including credit lending. This shift has potential implications for fairness, efficiency, and market structure.
research_question: What is the impact of automated decision-making systems on credit lending outcomes, such as loan approval rates, default rates, and borrower welfare?
data: Data from a randomized experiment in auto lending, comparing outcomes for loans processed by automated systems versus traditional human underwriters.
methods: A randomized controlled trial (RCT) where loan applications are randomly assigned to either an automated decision-making system or a human underwriter. Analysis of loan approval, default, and borrower characteristics.
main_results: Automated systems can increase lending efficiency and potentially reduce bias in some cases, but they may also perpetuate or even amplify existing biases if not carefully designed. The study finds that automated systems can lead to different lending decisions compared to human underwriters, with varying impacts on different borrower groups.
implications: The adoption of AI in lending requires careful consideration of ethical implications, fairness, and potential biases. Robust testing and monitoring are essential to ensure that automated systems serve borrowers equitably.

title: Stock Return Autocorrelations and Expected Option Returns
background: The autocorrelation of stock returns (i.e., the tendency for past returns to predict future returns) is a key characteristic studied in financial markets. This research explores its relationship with option returns.
research_question: How does the autocorrelation of underlying stock returns affect the expected returns of options written on those stocks?
data: Data on stock returns, option prices, and relevant market factors.
methods: Theoretical modeling and empirical analysis of the relationship between stock return autocorrelation and option pricing. The study likely uses statistical methods to estimate autocorrelation and option returns.
main_results: Stock return autocorrelation has a significant impact on expected option returns. Positive autocorrelation (momentum) tends to increase the value of call options and decrease the value of put options, while negative autocorrelation (reversal) has the opposite effect.
implications: Understanding stock return autocorrelation is crucial for accurately pricing options and for investors seeking to profit from option strategies. This finding has implications for portfolio management and risk assessment.

title: A High-Dimensional Choice Model for Online Retailers
background: Online retailers face a complex environment with a vast number of products and customer choices. Developing accurate models of consumer choice is essential for optimizing product assortment, pricing, and marketing.
research_question: How can we develop a choice model that effectively captures consumer preferences in high-dimensional online retail environments?
data: Customer choice data from online retail platforms, including product attributes, purchase history, and browsing behavior.
methods: Development of a new choice model designed to handle a large number of products and attributes. This likely involves techniques from econometrics and machine learning, such as latent variable models or regularization methods.
main_results: The proposed high-dimensional choice model provides more accurate predictions of consumer purchasing behavior compared to traditional models. It can identify key drivers of choice even when faced with a massive product catalog.
implications: Online retailers can use this model to improve their understanding of customer preferences, leading to better product recommendations, optimized inventory management, and more effective marketing strategies.

title: Distortions Caused by Lending Fee Retention
background: Some financial intermediaries, such as mutual funds, retain a portion of the lending fees generated from their assets. This practice can create distortions in investment decisions and market behavior.
research_question: How does the retention of lending fees by intermediaries distort investment decisions and affect market outcomes?
data: Data on mutual funds, their lending activities, fee structures, and investment portfolios.
methods: Econometric analysis to examine the relationship between fee retention policies and fund investment strategies, asset allocation, and performance.
main_results: Funds that retain lending fees tend to engage in more lending activities, potentially at the expense of other investment objectives or risk management considerations. This can lead to suboptimal portfolio construction and affect the pricing of securities involved in lending.
implications: Investors and regulators should be aware of the potential conflicts of interest and distortions arising from lending fee retention. This practice may warrant closer scrutiny to ensure alignment with investor interests.

title: Social Learning in Prosumption: Evidence from Online Communities
background: The rise of 'prosumption' (consumers who also produce or contribute content) in online communities creates new dynamics for learning and decision-making. Social interactions play a key role.
research_question: How does social learning occur within online prosumer communities, and how does it influence individual behavior and collective outcomes?
data: Data from online communities where users both consume and contribute information or products (e.g., open-source software communities, online forums for specific hobbies).
methods: Analysis of user interactions, content contributions, and adoption patterns within these communities. Network analysis and agent-based modeling may be used to understand social learning dynamics.
main_results: Social learning in prosumer communities is driven by factors such as the visibility of contributions, the credibility of users, and the structure of social networks. Users learn from each other's experiences, leading to faster adoption of new ideas or products and the formation of collective knowledge.
implications: Understanding social learning mechanisms is crucial for designing and managing online communities effectively. It can inform strategies for fostering collaboration, knowledge sharing, and innovation.

title: Can Improvements to Mobile Internet Service Help Developing Countries?
background: Access to quality mobile internet service is increasingly seen as a driver of economic development. However, the specific impact of improvements in service quality in developing countries needs empirical investigation.
research_question: What are the economic and social impacts of improvements in mobile internet service quality (e.g., speed, reliability) in developing countries?
data: Data on mobile internet service quality metrics, economic indicators (e.g., GDP, employment, business creation), and social indicators (e.g., education, access to information) for developing countries.
methods: Econometric analysis, potentially using quasi-experimental methods, to link changes in mobile internet quality to economic and social development outcomes.
main_results: Improvements in mobile internet service quality have a positive impact on economic growth, business activity, and access to information and education in developing countries. The benefits are often more pronounced in regions with lower initial levels of digital infrastructure.
implications: Investing in and improving mobile internet infrastructure in developing countries can be a powerful tool for fostering economic development and improving living standards.

title: The Competition for Partners in Matching Markets
background: Matching markets, where individuals or firms are paired based on preferences (e.g., dating markets, labor markets, kidney exchange), are characterized by competition for desirable partners.
research_question: How does competition for partners in matching markets affect the stability and efficiency of the resulting matches?
data: Theoretical modeling of matching markets with competition.
methods: Development of a game-theoretic model that incorporates competition among participants for partners. Analysis of equilibrium outcomes and the properties of the resulting matching.
main_results: Competition can lead to more efficient matches in some cases, as participants are incentivized to offer better terms or signal their desirability more effectively. However, intense competition can also lead to strategic behavior that may reduce overall welfare or create unstable outcomes.
implications: Understanding the dynamics of competition in matching markets is important for designing effective allocation mechanisms in various social and economic contexts.

title: Information Disclosure and Competitive Dynamics
background: Firms often face strategic decisions about how much information to disclose to competitors and customers. This disclosure can significantly influence competitive dynamics and market outcomes.
research_question: How does the strategic disclosure of information by firms affect competition, innovation, and market structure?
data: Theoretical modeling of firm competition and information strategy.
methods: A game-theoretic model analyzing firms' decisions to disclose information (e.g., about costs, product quality, R&D) in an oligopolistic market. Examination of equilibrium outcomes under different disclosure regimes.
main_results: The strategic disclosure of information can intensify or mitigate competition depending on the nature of the information and the market structure. Full disclosure may lead to intense price competition, while selective disclosure can be used to signal commitment or deter entry.
implications: Firms need to carefully consider the strategic implications of their information disclosure policies. Regulators may also need to consider disclosure requirements to promote fair competition.

title: Imperfect Targeting and Advertising Strategies
background: Advertisers aim to reach specific consumer segments, but targeting is often imperfect due to data limitations or consumer heterogeneity. This imperfect targeting influences advertising strategy.
research_question: How do firms adjust their advertising strategies when targeting is imperfect, and what are the implications for advertising effectiveness and consumer welfare?
data: Data on advertising campaigns, consumer demographics, and purchase behavior.
methods: Econometric modeling of advertising effectiveness under conditions of imperfect targeting. This may involve analyzing data from online advertising platforms or field experiments.
main_results: Imperfect targeting leads firms to adopt broader advertising strategies, potentially reaching consumers who are not the primary target. This can increase advertising costs but may also lead to positive spillover effects or discovery by new customer segments. The optimal strategy balances reach and precision.
implications: Advertisers need to account for the realities of imperfect targeting when designing campaigns. Consumers may be exposed to more advertising, but also potentially discover products they might not have otherwise considered.

title: Number Processing Constraints and Earnings News
background: Neuroscience suggests that human brains have limitations in processing numerical information. This study investigates how these cognitive constraints might affect how investors react to earnings news.
research_question: Do cognitive constraints in number processing influence investor reactions to corporate earnings announcements?
data: Event study data on stock price reactions to earnings announcements, combined with measures of the complexity or magnitude of the reported numbers.
methods: Analysis of stock market reactions to earnings news, examining whether the way numbers are presented (e.g., large vs. small numbers, positive vs. negative framing) affects the magnitude or speed of the reaction, consistent with cognitive processing limitations.
main_results: Investor reactions to earnings news are influenced by number processing constraints. For example, investors may react more strongly to news presented in a way that is easier to process, or they may exhibit biases related to anchoring or magnitude effects.
implications: Understanding these cognitive biases can help investors make more rational decisions and help companies communicate financial information more effectively to avoid misinterpretations.

title: Strategy-Proof Multi-Issue Mediation: An Application to Divorce Settlements
background: Mediation is a common method for resolving disputes, but it can be vulnerable to strategic manipulation by participants. This paper focuses on designing mediation mechanisms that are strategy-proof.
research_question: Can we design multi-issue mediation mechanisms that are strategy-proof, ensuring that participants cannot benefit by misrepresenting their preferences, particularly in contexts like divorce settlements?
data: Theoretical modeling of mechanism design and game theory.
methods: Development of a formal model of multi-issue mediation and the design of a mechanism that satisfies strategy-proofness. The application to divorce settlements provides a concrete context for analysis.
main_results: It is possible to design strategy-proof mediation mechanisms for multi-issue disputes, although these mechanisms may involve specific protocols for preference revelation and outcome determination. The proposed mechanism ensures that truthful reporting of preferences leads to the best possible outcome for each participant.
implications: This research offers a theoretical framework for improving the fairness and efficiency of mediation processes in various contexts, including legal disputes, business negotiations, and resource allocation.

title: Expectation Formation Under Uninformative Signals
background: Individuals and firms often receive signals about future outcomes, but these signals may not always be informative. Understanding how expectations are formed in such situations is crucial.
research_question: How do agents form expectations when they receive signals that are uninformative or only weakly informative about future events?
data: Theoretical modeling of agent behavior and expectation formation.
methods: Development of a model that captures how agents process information, particularly when signals are noisy or misleading. Analysis of the resulting expectation dynamics and their impact on decision-making.
main_results: When signals are uninformative, agents may rely on other heuristics, social learning, or past experiences to form expectations. This can lead to persistent biases or inefficient decision-making, as agents may overreact to noise or fail to update their beliefs appropriately.
implications: This research has implications for understanding market behavior, policy effectiveness, and individual decision-making in environments characterized by uncertainty and imperfect information.

title: The Value of Competitor Information: Evidence from Online Labor Markets
background: In competitive markets, understanding competitors' actions and strategies is valuable. This study examines the value of competitor information in online labor markets.
research_question: How does access to information about competitors' pricing and offerings affect firms' strategic decisions and performance in online labor markets?
data: Data from online labor platforms, including information on freelancer pricing, project bids, and client reviews.
methods: Analysis of how freelancers adjust their bids and pricing strategies when they have access to information about competitors' bids on the same projects. This could involve quasi-experimental designs or regression discontinuity.
main_results: Access to competitor information significantly influences freelancers' pricing decisions, often leading to more competitive bidding. However, it can also result in a 'race to the bottom' in terms of pricing, potentially reducing overall earnings for freelancers.
implications: Online labor platforms can influence market dynamics through the information they provide about competitors. Understanding these effects is important for platform design and for freelancers seeking to optimize their strategies.

title: Corporate Social Responsibility and Consumer Choices
background: Consumers are increasingly aware of and concerned about corporate social responsibility (CSR). This study investigates how CSR initiatives influence consumer purchasing decisions.
research_question: To what extent do corporate social responsibility initiatives affect consumer choices, and under what conditions are these effects most pronounced?
data: Survey data or experimental data linking consumer perceptions of CSR with their purchasing intentions and actual choices.
methods: Econometric analysis of survey data or results from controlled experiments where consumers are exposed to different levels and types of CSR information.
main_results: Consumers do respond to CSR initiatives, with positive CSR performance often leading to increased purchase likelihood and willingness to pay a premium. However, the impact varies depending on the type of CSR activity, the industry, and consumer demographics.
implications: Firms can leverage CSR as a strategic tool to enhance brand reputation and influence consumer behavior. However, authenticity and effective communication of CSR efforts are crucial for success.

title: LIBOR Discontinuation and the Cost of Bank Loans
background: The London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) is being phased out and replaced by alternative reference rates. This transition has implications for financial contracts, including bank loans.
research_question: What is the impact of the LIBOR discontinuation and transition to alternative rates on the cost of bank loans for borrowers?
data: Data on bank loans, including their interest rates, reference rates, and maturity, before and after the LIBOR transition period.
methods: Event study analysis or difference-in-differences approach to estimate the change in loan costs associated with the LIBOR transition, controlling for other factors affecting interest rates.
main_results: The transition away from LIBOR has led to changes in the cost of bank loans. Borrowers may face increased costs due to the uncertainty surrounding new reference rates, the complexity of contract adjustments, and potential differences in liquidity between LIBOR and its successors.
implications: Borrowers and lenders need to carefully manage the transition from LIBOR to new reference rates to mitigate potential increases in borrowing costs and ensure smooth contract renegotiations.

title: The Effect of Computer Monitoring on Employees
background: Organizations increasingly use computer monitoring to track employee activity. This practice can have various effects on employee behavior, productivity, and well-being.
research_question: What are the effects of computer monitoring on employee productivity, job satisfaction, and perceived fairness?
data: Data from a study where employees are subjected to different levels or types of computer monitoring, linked with measures of their performance and attitudes.
methods: An empirical study, potentially involving a field experiment or quasi-experiment, to measure the impact of computer monitoring on employee outcomes.
main_results: Computer monitoring can lead to increased productivity in some tasks by reducing distractions and encouraging focus. However, it can also negatively impact employee morale, job satisfaction, and trust, especially if perceived as excessive or unfair.
implications: Firms should carefully consider the trade-offs associated with computer monitoring, balancing the potential gains in productivity with the risks to employee well-being and organizational culture.

title: The Cost of Impatience in Dynamic Matching: Stochastic Scheduling
background: In dynamic matching processes (e.g., job matching, dating), impatience can lead individuals to accept suboptimal matches or abandon the search process prematurely. This study analyzes the cost of such impatience.
research_question: How does impatience affect the efficiency and outcomes of dynamic matching processes, and what is the 'cost' of impatience in terms of lost utility or suboptimal matches?
data: Theoretical modeling of dynamic matching with stochastic arrivals and impatient agents.
methods: Development of a stochastic scheduling model that incorporates agent impatience. Analysis of optimal strategies and the resulting equilibrium outcomes.
main_results: Impatience significantly increases the cost of search in dynamic matching markets. Impatient agents are more likely to accept lower-quality matches or fail to find a match altogether, leading to reduced overall welfare.
implications: Understanding the cost of impatience is important for designing effective matching platforms and for individuals seeking to navigate these markets successfully. Strategies to mitigate impatience or provide better information can improve outcomes.

title: Politically Affiliated Analysts
background: Financial analysts' recommendations can be influenced by various factors, including their political affiliations. This study examines the impact of such affiliations on analyst behavior.
research_question: Do financial analysts' political affiliations affect their stock recommendations, forecast accuracy, and the market's reaction to their reports?
data: Data on financial analysts, their stock recommendations, earnings forecasts, and their political affiliations (e.g., campaign donations).
methods: Econometric analysis to link analysts' political affiliations with their recommendation behavior and forecast performance, controlling for other relevant factors.
main_results: Analysts with strong political affiliations may exhibit biased recommendations, favoring companies or industries aligned with their political views. This bias can lead to less accurate forecasts and potentially affect market efficiency.
implications: Investors should be aware of potential biases in analyst recommendations stemming from political affiliations. This highlights the importance of independent research and due diligence.

title: Kinks as Goals: Accelerating Commissions and the "Kink" Effect
background: Sales commissions often have 'kinks'  points where the commission rate changes abruptly. This study investigates how these kinks influence sales behavior, particularly in accelerating sales towards these points.
research_question: Do sales agents strategically accelerate their sales to reach commission 'kinks' (target levels), and what are the consequences for sales performance and customer behavior?
data: Sales data from firms with piecewise-linear commission structures, potentially including information on sales timing and customer interactions.
methods: Analysis of sales data to identify patterns of accelerated sales activity around commission kinks. This could involve regression discontinuity designs or time-series analysis.
main_results: Sales agents do exhibit a 'kink effect,' strategically accelerating their sales efforts as they approach commission thresholds. This can lead to front-loading of sales and potentially impact the quality of customer interactions or the timing of purchases.
implications: Firms designing commission structures should be aware of the behavioral responses to kinks. These structures can incentivize certain behaviors but may also lead to unintended consequences.

title: Can Random Friends Seed More Buzz and Adoption?
background: In the context of social networks and word-of-mouth marketing, the diversity of one's social connections might influence the spread of information and the adoption of new products or ideas.
research_question: Does having a more diverse set of social connections (i.e., 'random friends') lead to greater 'buzz' and faster adoption of new products or ideas?
data: Data from social networks, potentially involving experiments where users are exposed to information through diverse or homogeneous networks.
methods: Analysis of information diffusion and adoption patterns in social networks, possibly using simulations or field experiments to compare outcomes with different network structures.
main_results: Introducing 'random friends' or connections outside of one's immediate social circle can indeed seed more buzz and accelerate adoption. Diverse networks provide access to novel information and perspectives, increasing the reach and impact of new ideas.
implications: Marketers and social platforms can leverage network diversity to enhance the spread of information and promote product adoption. Individuals can also benefit from actively cultivating diverse social connections.

title: Social Preferences and the Informativeness of Subjective Signals
background: Individuals often rely on subjective signals (e.g., opinions, advice) when making decisions. This study examines how social preferences (e.g., altruism, reciprocity) influence the perceived informativeness of these signals.
research_question: How do social preferences affect an individual's belief updating process when receiving subjective signals from others?
data: Experimental data from behavioral economics studies involving decision-making with subjective signals and varying social contexts.
methods: Laboratory experiments where participants make decisions based on signals from others, with manipulations of social preferences (e.g., through rewards, punishments, or relationship framing). Analysis of belief updating and decision outcomes.
main_results: Social preferences significantly influence how individuals interpret and use subjective signals. For instance, altruistic individuals might place more weight on signals from those they believe are acting in the best interest of others, while reciprocity concerns might lead to different weighting schemes.
implications: Understanding the role of social preferences is crucial for fields ranging from marketing and organizational behavior to political science, where subjective information plays a key role in shaping opinions and actions.

title: Does Mining Fuel Bubbles? An Experimental Study
background: The mining of cryptocurrencies and other digital assets has been associated with significant price volatility and speculative behavior. This study uses an experiment to investigate the link between mining and asset bubbles.
research_question: Does the process of mining digital assets contribute to the formation and amplification of asset bubbles?
data: An experimental study simulating a market for a digital asset where participants can engage in 'mining' activities.
methods: A controlled laboratory experiment where participants can mine a digital asset, trade it, and observe its price. The experiment is designed to isolate the effect of mining on price dynamics and bubble formation.
main_results: The experimental results suggest that mining activities can exacerbate asset bubbles. The process of mining can create a perception of scarcity or intrinsic value, encouraging speculative investment and leading to prices that deviate significantly from fundamental values.
implications: This research provides experimental evidence on a potential driver of speculative bubbles in digital asset markets, highlighting the need for careful consideration of the economic incentives created by mining mechanisms.

title: Robbing Peter to Pay Paul: The Impact of California's Net Neutrality Law
background: Net neutrality regulations aim to ensure that internet service providers treat all internet traffic equally. This study examines the economic consequences of California's specific net neutrality law.

While it may protect consumers from certain discriminatory practices, it could also disincentivize investment in network infrastructure by ISPs, potentially leading to slower overall network development or shifts in how services are offered ('robbing Peter to pay Paul').
implications: Policymakers need to carefully consider the complex economic trade-offs when designing and implementing net neutrality regulations, as they can have far-reaching consequences for the digital ecosystem.

Individuals may express strong concerns about privacy but make choices that lead to significant data disclosure, suggesting that other factors (e.g., convenience, social norms, lack of understanding) influence their decisions.
implications: Businesses and policymakers need to be cautious about relying solely on stated preferences when designing privacy policies or products. Understanding the drivers of revealed preferences is key to developing effective privacy solutions.

title: The Effects of Health Information Exchange Access on Care Coordination and Patient Outcomes
background: Health Information Exchanges (HIEs) aim to improve healthcare delivery by facilitating the sharing of patient information among providers. Their impact on care coordination and patient outcomes is of interest.
research_question: What are the effects of Health Information Exchange (HIE) access on care coordination and patient outcomes?
data: Data on HIE implementation, healthcare provider interactions, and patient health outcomes.
methods: Empirical analysis of the impact of HIEs on healthcare delivery and patient results.
main_results: The study investigates how HIEs influence care coordination and ultimately affect patient health outcomes.
implications: This research can inform the design and implementation of health information systems to improve the quality and efficiency of healthcare.

title: Empirical Model of Dynamic Merger Enforcement
background: Merger enforcement by regulatory bodies is crucial for maintaining competition. Developing empirical models to assess the effectiveness of these policies is important.
research_question: How can we develop an empirical model to evaluate the dynamic effects of merger enforcement policies?
data: Data on mergers, market competition, and regulatory decisions.
methods: Introduction of a method to conduct a forward-looking empirical analysis of merger enforcement.
main_results: The paper presents a novel empirical approach for assessing the impact of merger enforcement, considering dynamic market effects.
implications: This can help antitrust authorities make more informed decisions about merger reviews and policy design.

title: Shareholder Short-Termism, Corporate Control, and Investment
background: The focus of shareholders on short-term gains can influence corporate decision-making, particularly regarding long-term investments and corporate control.
research_question: How does shareholder short-termism affect corporate control dynamics and the level of corporate investment?
data: Data on shareholder behavior, corporate governance, and investment levels.
methods: Examination of how managers use voluntary disclosures in response to shareholder short-termism and its impact on investment.
main_results: The study investigates the relationship between shareholder short-termism, managerial actions related to corporate control, and the resulting investment decisions.
implications: This research highlights the potential conflicts between short-term shareholder interests and long-term corporate value creation.

title: Herding in Probabilistic Forecasts
background: Herding behavior, where individuals follow the actions of a larger group, can occur in forecasting. Understanding its dynamics in probabilistic forecasts is important.
research_question: How does herding behavior manifest in probabilistic forecasting, and what are its implications for forecast accuracy and decision-making?
data: Data on probabilistic forecasts from multiple experts or agents.
methods: Analysis of herding behavior in probabilistic forecasts.
main_results: The paper examines how decision-makers might conform to the forecasts of others, even when those forecasts are probabilistic, and the consequences of such behavior.
implications: This has implications for the reliability of expert opinions and the design of forecasting systems.

title: Right to Repair: Pricing, Welfare, and Environmental Implications
background: The 'right to repair' movement advocates for consumers' ability to repair their products. This has potential implications for pricing, consumer welfare, and environmental sustainability.
research_question: What are the economic, welfare, and environmental consequences of 'right to repair' policies?
data: Economic modeling and analysis of pricing, welfare, and environmental impacts.
methods: Analysis of pricing, welfare, and environmental outcomes related to the 'right to repair'.
main_results: The study explores how 'right to repair' policies affect product pricing, consumer welfare, and environmental outcomes.
implications: This research can inform policy debates surrounding product longevity, repairability, and sustainability.

title: The Real Effects of Implicit Government Guarantees
background: Implicit government guarantees can influence the behavior of firms and financial institutions, but their 'real effects' on the economy are not always clear.
research_question: What are the actual economic consequences of implicit government guarantees on firms and markets?
data: Data on firms and markets subject to implicit government guarantees.
methods: Study of the effects of implicit government guarantees on economic activities.
main_results: The research investigates how implicit government backing influences firm behavior, risk-taking, and market dynamics.
implications: This has implications for financial regulation, industrial policy, and understanding the role of government intervention in the economy.

title: Privacy and Market Concentration: Intended and Unintended Consequences
background: Privacy regulations, such as those concerning vendor use of consumer data, can have complex effects on market structure and competition.
research_question: How do privacy regulations concerning vendor data usage impact market concentration and competition, considering both intended and unintended consequences?
data: Data on vendor practices, consumer data usage, and market concentration metrics.
methods: Analysis of how websites' vendor use changes after privacy-related policy shifts and its impact on market concentration.
main_results: The study shows that changes in vendor data usage following privacy-related policy shifts can affect market concentration, with both intended and unintended outcomes.
implications: This research is relevant for policymakers designing privacy regulations and for businesses navigating data privacy landscapes.

title: Belief Dispersion and Convex Cost of Adjustment
background: In economic models, the cost of adjusting firm behavior or investment is often assumed to be convex. How belief dispersion interacts with these costs is an area of study.
research_question: How does the dispersion of beliefs among economic agents affect decisions when there are convex costs of adjustment?
data: Theoretical framework for general equilibrium models.
methods: Development of a continuous-time general equilibrium model to analyze belief dispersion and adjustment costs.
main_results: The model explores how heterogeneous beliefs interact with adjustment costs to influence economic dynamics and decision-making.
implications: This research can help understand macroeconomic phenomena and firm-level responses in environments with diverse expectations.

title: Personalized Pricing and Distribution Strategies
background: The availability of consumer data allows firms to implement personalized pricing and distribution strategies, which can significantly alter market dynamics.
research_question: How does the availability of consumer data enable personalized pricing and distribution strategies, and what are their implications for firms and consumers?
data: Data on consumer behavior, pricing strategies, and distribution channels.
methods: Analysis of how consumer data availability influences personalized pricing and distribution strategies.
main_results: The study examines how firms leverage consumer data to tailor prices and distribution methods, impacting market outcomes.
implications: This research is relevant for understanding modern marketing practices, competition, and consumer welfare in data-driven markets.

title: Treatment Effect Risk: Bounds and Inference
background: Estimating the causal effect of treatments or interventions is a core task in many fields. Understanding the uncertainty and bounds of these estimates is crucial.
research_question: How can we effectively bound and infer treatment effects, especially when dealing with potential risks or uncertainties in the data?
data: Statistical and econometric methods for causal inference.
methods: Development of methods for bounding and inferring treatment effects, considering potential risks.
main_results: The paper focuses on providing robust methods for estimating treatment effects, including techniques to establish bounds and perform reliable inference.
implications: This research contributes to more rigorous causal analysis in various domains, including policy evaluation and scientific research.

title: Stochastic Optimization Forests
background: Stochastic optimization problems involve uncertainty. Ensemble methods like random forests are powerful for prediction, and their application to optimization is an area of interest.
research_question: How can stochastic optimization problems be addressed using ensemble methods like random forests?
data: Theoretical framework and potentially simulation data for stochastic optimization.
methods: Study of contextual stochastic optimization problems using ensemble methods.
main_results: The research explores the application of ensemble learning techniques to solve complex stochastic optimization problems.
implications: This could lead to more effective solutions for decision-making under uncertainty in various fields, such as operations research and machine learning.

title: Mixing It Up: Operational Impact of Hospitalists
background: Hospitalists are physicians specializing in hospital care. Their role and impact on hospital operations and patient care delivery are important to understand.
research_question: What is the operational impact of hospitalists on hospital efficiency and patient care?
data: Data on hospital operations, patient flow, and care coordination involving hospitalists.
methods: Analysis of the operational impact of hospitalists, focusing on their specialization and integration into care delivery.
main_results: The study examines how the presence and practices of hospitalists affect hospital operations, potentially influencing efficiency and quality of care.
implications: This research can inform hospital management and healthcare policy regarding the optimal use of hospitalist services.

title: The Square Root Agreement Rule for Incentivizing Information Sharing
background: Incentivizing individuals or firms to share valuable information is a challenge. New rules or mechanisms may be needed to encourage this.
research_question: Can a 'square root agreement rule' effectively incentivize information sharing among parties?
data: Theoretical framework and potentially experimental data on information sharing incentives.
methods: Analysis of a novel incentive mechanism, the 'square root agreement rule', for information sharing.
main_results: The study proposes and analyzes a specific rule designed to encourage information sharing, evaluating its effectiveness.
implications: This has implications for designing contracts and agreements in situations where information exchange is critical.

title: Free Riding and Workplace DemocracyHeterogeneous Preferences
background: Workplace democracy involves collective decision-making, but free-riding behavior can undermine these efforts. Heterogeneous preferences can further complicate this.
research_question: How do free-riding incentives and heterogeneous preferences affect participation and outcomes in workplace democracy?
data: Experimental data from a laboratory setting examining workplace democracy scenarios.
methods: A novel laboratory experiment is used to study free-riding and workplace democracy with heterogeneous preferences.
main_results: The experiment demonstrates how free-riding dynamics and differing preferences influence collective decision-making and participation in a democratic workplace setting.
implications: This research offers insights into designing more effective participatory work environments and understanding collective action problems.

title: When Should the Off-Grid Sun Shine at Night? Optimal Contracting for Solar Energy
background: Providing reliable energy access to off-grid populations, particularly through solar power, requires effective contracting and operational strategies, especially considering intermittency.
research_question: What are the optimal contracting strategies for providing solar energy services to off-grid communities, considering the challenges of intermittency?
data: Data from off-grid solar energy projects and economic modeling.
methods: Analysis of optimal contracting for solar energy in off-grid settings, addressing intermittency.
main_results: The study addresses the challenges of providing consistent solar energy in off-grid areas through optimal contract design.
implications: This research can guide the development of sustainable energy solutions for underserved populations.

title: Estimating Effects of Incentive Contracts in Online Labor Markets
background: Online labor markets rely on various incentive contracts to motivate workers and clients. Estimating the true effects of these contracts is important for market design.
research_question: What are the effects of different performance-based incentive contracts on worker effort and outcomes in online labor markets?
data: Data from online labor platforms on contract types, worker performance, and task completion.
methods: Estimation of the effects of incentive contracts in online labor markets.
main_results: The paper estimates the impact of performance-based incentives on worker behavior and outcomes in online gig economy platforms.
implications: This research can help optimize contract design in online labor markets to improve efficiency and worker satisfaction.

title: Privacy Rights and Data Security: GDPR and Personal Data
background: Regulations like the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) aim to protect individuals' privacy rights and enhance data security concerning personal data.
research_question: What are the implications of the GDPR for privacy rights and data security concerning personal data?
data: Analysis of the GDPR and its impact on data handling practices.
methods: Examination of the GDPR's impact on privacy rights and data security.
main_results: The study analyzes how the GDPR influences the protection of personal data and the enforcement of privacy rights.
implications: This research is relevant for understanding the regulatory landscape of data privacy and its effects on businesses and individuals.

title: Attracting the Sharks: Corporate Innovation and Investment
background: Attracting significant investment, often referred to metaphorically as 'sharks', is crucial for corporate innovation and growth. Understanding what attracts such investment is key.
research_question: What factors attract significant corporate investment, particularly for fostering innovation?
data: Data on corporate innovation activities and investment patterns.
methods: Providing novel evidence on factors influencing corporate innovation and investment attraction.
main_results: The paper offers new insights into the drivers that attract substantial investment into corporate innovation initiatives.
implications: This research can guide firms in developing strategies to secure funding for innovative projects.

title: Analyzing Active Fund Managers' Commitment to ESG
background: Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investing is growing, but the genuine commitment of active fund managers to ESG principles needs scrutiny.
research_question: How can we analyze and measure the commitment of active fund managers to ESG principles?
data: Data on the investment strategies and holdings of active fund managers.
methods: Analysis of active fund managers' commitment to ESG principles, potentially using data from the UN Principles for Responsible Investment.
main_results: The study examines how to assess the actual adherence of fund managers to ESG mandates.
implications: This research is important for investors seeking to align their portfolios with ESG values and for holding fund managers accountable.

title: Disclosure of Disaggregated Information in the Financial Markets
background: The level of detail in financial disclosures can impact market efficiency and investor decision-making. Disaggregated information may offer different insights than aggregated data.
research_question: How does the disclosure of disaggregated financial information affect market outcomes and investor behavior?
data: Data on financial disclosures and market reactions.
methods: Examination of a reputation-concerned entity's disclosure of disaggregated information.
main_results: The study investigates the impact of providing more granular financial information on market perceptions and decisions.
implications: This research can inform corporate disclosure policies and regulatory requirements for financial reporting.

title: Rising Temperatures, Falling Ratings: The Effect of Climate Change on Corporate Ratings
background: Climate change is a growing concern, and its potential impact on corporate performance and credit ratings is an area of increasing interest.
research_question: How do rising temperatures and climate change affect corporate credit ratings?
data: Data on climate indicators, corporate financial performance, and credit ratings.
methods: Analysis of the relationship between climate change indicators and corporate ratings.
main_results: The study finds a correlation between rising temperatures and declining corporate ratings, suggesting climate change impacts financial risk.
implications: This research highlights the financial risks associated with climate change and the need for 'greening the financial system'.

title: Learning Outside the Classroom During a Pandemic
background: The COVID-19 pandemic forced a shift to remote learning, impacting educational experiences. Understanding how students learn outside the traditional classroom setting is crucial.
research_question: How do students learn and adapt their learning strategies outside the traditional classroom, especially during a pandemic?
data: Data on student learning behaviors and outcomes during remote learning periods.
methods: Drawing on the notion of compensatory behavior to understand learning outside the classroom.
main_results: The study examines how students adjust their learning approaches when formal classroom instruction is disrupted, potentially through compensatory behaviors.
implications: This research can inform educational strategies for remote and hybrid learning environments.

title: The Good, the Bad, and the Unhirable: Recommender Systems in Hiring
background: Recommender systems are increasingly used in various applications, including hiring. Their impact on the selection process and the types of candidates recommended needs examination.
research_question: How do recommender systems used in hiring processes affect the selection of candidates, and what are the implications of 'good', 'bad', and 'unhirable' recommendations?
data: Data from online labor markets on hiring decisions and recommender system outputs.
methods: Analysis of candidate selection in online labor markets, focusing on recommender systems.
main_results: The study analyzes how recommender systems influence hiring decisions, categorizing recommendations and their impact on candidate employability.
implications: This research is relevant for the design and ethical considerations of AI-driven hiring tools.

title: Learning to Successfully Hire in Online Labor Markets
background: Hiring in online labor markets presents unique challenges. Firms need to develop effective strategies and learn how to successfully recruit talent through these platforms.
research_question: What strategies and learning processes enable firms to successfully hire workers in online labor markets?
data: Data on hiring practices and outcomes in online labor markets.
methods: Study of how firms learn to effectively hire in online labor markets.
main_results: The paper investigates the learning curve and effective strategies for employers operating in online labor platforms.
implications: This research can help businesses improve their recruitment processes in the gig economy.

title: Ambiguity Aversion and Beating Benchmarks: Does It Matter?
background: Ambiguity aversion (a preference for known risks over unknown ones) can influence investment decisions. Its impact on the ability of analysts to outperform market benchmarks is a question.
research_question: Does ambiguity aversion among financial analysts affect their ability to beat market benchmarks?
data: Data on analyst forecasts and market benchmark performance.
methods: Analysis of the relationship between ambiguity aversion and analyst forecast performance.
main_results: The study examines whether analysts' aversion to ambiguity influences their success in outperforming market benchmarks.
implications: This has implications for understanding investor behavior, market efficiency, and the role of uncertainty in financial analysis.

title: Indoor Air Quality and Strategic Decision Making
background: The physical environment in which decisions are made can influence cognitive processes and strategic choices. Indoor air quality is one such environmental factor.
research_question: How does indoor air quality affect strategic decision-making in the workplace?
data: Data on indoor air quality metrics and decision-making outcomes in organizational settings.
methods: Study of the impact of indoor air quality on strategic decision-making.
main_results: The research investigates the link between the quality of indoor air and the strategic choices made by individuals and groups in organizational contexts.
implications: This highlights the importance of workplace environment on productivity and decision quality.

title: Employment Flexibility and Capital Structure
background: The flexibility of employment arrangements can have implications for a firm's financial decisions, including its capital structure.
research_question: How does employment flexibility influence a firm's capital structure decisions?
data: Panel data set of manufacturing firms to analyze employment flexibility and capital structure.
methods: Empirical analysis using a unique panel data set of manufacturing firms.
main_results: The study examines the relationship between the degree of employment flexibility and how firms finance their operations (capital structure).
implications: This research can inform corporate finance and human resource management strategies.

title: Explaining Excess Entry in Winner-Take-All Markets
background: Winner-take-all markets, where a single firm or individual captures most of the rewards, can sometimes experience excessive entry, which needs explanation.
research_question: What factors explain the phenomenon of excess entry into winner-take-all markets?
data: Experimental data from standard market experiments.
methods: Reporting experimental data from standard market entry experiments.
main_results: The study uses experimental data to understand why firms might enter markets where only one player can win, leading to potentially inefficient outcomes.
implications: This research can inform market design and competition policy in industries with strong network effects or superstar dynamics.

title: CDS Trading Initiation, Information Asymmetry, and Market Liquidity
background: Credit Default Swap (CDS) markets play a role in risk management, but the initiation of trading and its relationship with information asymmetry and market liquidity are complex.
research_question: How does the initiation of CDS trading relate to information asymmetry and subsequent market liquidity?
data: Data from CDS markets, focusing on trading initiation and liquidity measures.
methods: Using an information-asymmetry framework to study CDS trading initiation.
main_results: The study investigates how the start of trading in CDS contracts is influenced by information asymmetries and how it, in turn, affects market liquidity.
implications: This research has implications for understanding the functioning of credit derivative markets and financial stability.

title: How to Alleviate Correlation Neglect in Investment Decisions
background: Investors sometimes neglect the correlation between different assets when making investment decisions, which can lead to suboptimal portfolio choices.
research_question: What methods or interventions can help investors overcome correlation neglect in their investment decisions?
data: Experimental data on investment decision-making under different presentation formats.
methods: Experimentally studying how presentation format influences investors' consideration of correlations.
main_results: The paper experimentally investigates how the way information is presented can help alleviate investors' tendency to ignore correlations between assets.
implications: This research can inform financial education and the design of investment tools to improve decision-making.

title: Profit Effects of Consumers Identity Management
background: Consumers' management of their identity, particularly in online contexts, can influence their purchasing behavior and affect firm profits.
research_question: How does consumers' management of their identity impact firm profits, especially for monopolists selling nondurable goods?
data: Economic modeling of a monopolist selling a nondurable good.
methods: Consideration of a nondurable good monopolist facing consumers who manage their identity.
main_results: The study analyzes how consumer identity management strategies affect the profitability of a monopolist.
implications: This research is relevant for understanding pricing and marketing strategies in industries where consumer identity plays a role.

title: The Worst-First Heuristic: How Decision Makers Choose
background: Decision makers often employ heuristics (mental shortcuts) to simplify complex choices. The 'worst-first' heuristic is one such strategy.
research_question: How do decision makers utilize the 'worst-first' heuristic when making choices, and what are the implications for managerial outcomes?
data: Data on managerial decision-making processes and outcomes.
methods: Analysis of how decision makers employ the 'worst-first' heuristic.
main_results: The paper examines the 'worst-first' heuristic and its role in shaping important managerial outcomes.
implications: Understanding these heuristics can help improve decision-making processes in organizations.

title: Economic and Environmental Implications of Biofuel Mandates
background: Biofuel mandates are policies designed to promote the use of biofuels, with potential economic and environmental consequences that need careful evaluation.
research_question: What are the economic and environmental impacts of biofuel mandates?
data: Economic modeling motivated by agricultural industries and biofuel production.
methods: Modeling the economic and environmental implications of biofuel mandates.
main_results: The study analyzes the consequences of biofuel mandates on the economy and the environment.
implications: This research can inform policy decisions regarding renewable energy and agricultural support.

title: Contracting for Product Support Under Information Asymmetry
background: Providing product support after a sale is crucial, but information asymmetry between the seller and buyer can complicate contracting for these services.
research_question: How should contracts for product support be designed when there is information asymmetry between the seller and the buyer?
data: Theoretical framework for contracting under information asymmetry.
methods: Analysis of contracting for product support under information asymmetry.
main_results: The paper examines how to structure contracts for after-sales product support when the seller and buyer have different levels of information.
implications: This research can help firms design more effective service contracts and improve customer satisfaction.

title: Estimating and Exploiting the Impact of Photo Quality on Airbnb
background: In online marketplaces like Airbnb, the quality of visual content, such as photos, can significantly influence consumer choices and platform performance.
research_question: How does the quality of host-generated photos impact booking decisions and revenue on platforms like Airbnb, and can this impact be exploited?
data: Data on Airbnb listings, including photos, booking rates, and pricing.
methods: Estimating and exploiting the impact of host-generated property images as a visual characteristic.
main_results: The study quantifies the effect of photo quality on Airbnb bookings and revenue, suggesting strategies to leverage this factor.
implications: This research provides insights for platform design, host strategies, and understanding the role of visual marketing.

title: What Makes Agility Fragile? A Dynamic Theory of Organizational Agility
background: Organizational agility, the ability to adapt quickly to change, is often seen as a strength. However, there might be conditions under which agility can become a vulnerability.
research_question: What factors contribute to the fragility of organizational agility, and how can organizations maintain it effectively?
data: Theoretical framework for organizational agility.
methods: Presentation of a novel explanation for why organizations might be agile yet fragile.
main_results: The paper offers a dynamic theory explaining how organizational agility can paradoxically lead to fragility.
implications: This research can help organizations build more robust and resilient adaptive capabilities.

title: Marketplace Scalability and Strategic Use of Pricing
background: The ability of a marketplace to scale, i.e., handle increasing numbers of users and transactions, is crucial for its success. Strategic pricing can play a role in this scalability.
research_question: How does marketplace scalability depend on the strategic use of pricing mechanisms?
data: Theoretical framework for marketplace dynamics.
methods: Analysis of marketplace scalability and strategic pricing.
main_results: The study examines the relationship between a marketplace's ability to scale and how pricing strategies are employed.
implications: This research is relevant for platform design, market management, and understanding the economics of two-sided markets.

title: Simple and Approximately Optimal Contracts for...
background: Many countries have adopted payment for ecosystem services (PES) schemes to incentivize landowners to protect their land. However, the design of these contracts is challenging due to information asymmetry and the complexity of ecological systems.
research_question: How can we design simple and approximately optimal contracts for PES schemes that account for landowner heterogeneity and ecological uncertainty?
data: The study uses a combination of theoretical modeling and simulation based on stylized ecological and economic parameters.
methods: The paper develops a theoretical framework for designing PES contracts under information asymmetry. It proposes a class of simple contracts that are approximately optimal and robust to variations in ecological outcomes.
main_results: The proposed simple contracts achieve a high level of efficiency, close to the first-best outcome, even with significant landowner heterogeneity and ecological uncertainty. The contracts are easy to implement and monitor.
implications: The findings provide practical guidance for policymakers designing PES schemes, suggesting that complex contracts are not always necessary and that simpler, well-structured contracts can be highly effective.

title: The Bright Side of Inequity Aversion
background: Modern consumers are concerned about not only their own outcomes but also the outcomes of others, a phenomenon known as inequity aversion. This can influence their purchasing decisions and market behavior.
research_question: Under what conditions does inequity aversion lead to socially beneficial outcomes in markets?
data: The study uses theoretical modeling and experimental economics to explore consumer behavior.
methods: The paper develops a theoretical model of consumer choice incorporating inequity aversion and then tests the model's predictions using laboratory experiments.
main_results: The results show that inequity aversion can lead consumers to make choices that benefit society, such as choosing higher-quality products or supporting more sustainable practices, even if it means a personal cost.
implications: Understanding inequity aversion can help firms and policymakers design markets and interventions that leverage this social preference for positive societal impact.

title: Buy-One-Get-One Promotions in a Two-Echelon Su...
background: Buy-one-get-one (BOGO) promotions are widely used by retailers to stimulate demand. However, their effectiveness can depend on the supply chain structure and the strategic interactions between manufacturers and retailers.
